questions.text: Identify which organism this life cycle belongs to.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Entamoeba histolytica

 

Explanation: The given diagram depicts the life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica.

 

E.histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and a wide range of other invasive diseases, including amoebic liver abscesses.

Morphology: Has three stages:

  1. Trophozoite
  2. Precyst
  3. Cyst

 

Life Cycle:

  • Host: Single host, i.e. man.
  • Infective form: Mature quadrinucleate cyst
  • Mode of transmission: E. histolytica is transmitted by
    • Feco-oral route (most common)
    • Sexual (anogenital or orogenital) contact
    • Very rarely by vectors (mechanical transmission from faeces).
  • Development in Human Intestine:
    • Small intestine: Undergoes excystation
    • Large intestine: Multiplication and colonization.
  • Manifestations:
    • Asymptomatic cyst passers
    • Amoebic dysentery
    • Invasive amoebiasis
  • Encystation: When the lesions start healing, and the patient improves, trophozoites transform into cysts and then into cysts in the large intestine, which are liberated in faeces. These cysts are infective.


 

Naegleria fowleri (Option A): The life cycle of Naegleria fowleri includes an infective trophozoite stage that enters through the nasal mucosa and a cyst stage that helps it survive in harsh conditions outside the host. Causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).


 

Acanthamoeba (Option C): Man acquires infection by inhalation of aerosols contaminated with cyst or trophozoite and causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis in immunocompromised and keratitis in contact lens users.

 

Giardia lamblia (Option D): The life cycle of Giardia lamblia involves ingestion of cysts from contaminated food or water. These cysts transform into trophozoites in the small intestine, multiply, and eventually form new cysts that are excreted in the feces to infect new hosts. This causes giardiasis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal pain and diarrhea after travelling to an area with poor sanitation. A histology of the intestinal mucosa obtained via colonoscopy revealed the following.



What is the infective form of the organism that causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cyst

 

Explanation: The given clinical history and the histology specimen showing a flask-shaped ulcer suggest amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. This organism's infective form is the cyst.

 

Entamoeba histolytica:

 

Life Cycle:

  • Host: Single host, i.e. man.
  • Infective form: Mature cyst containing
    • 1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate
    • Thick Chromatoid body/ bar
  • Mode of transmission: Feco-oral route (most common)
  • Development in Human Intestine:
    • Small intestine: Undergoes excystation.
    • Large intestine: Multiplication and colonization.
  • Manifestations:
    • Asymptomatic cyst passers
    • Amoebic dysentery
    • Invasive amoebiasis

questions.text: All of the following have a low infective dose except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vibrio cholerae

 

Explanation

Vibrio cholerae is highly acid-labile and hence requires a large infective dose of approximately 108 bacteria to overcome the gastric barrier.

 

Infective dose refers to the minimum dose required to initiate the infection. For example,

  • Infective dose of 10-100 bacteria or cysts (Mnemonic - CHHota SmaLL):
    • Cryptosporidium
    • Entamoeba Histolytica
    • EnteroHemorrhagic E. coli
    • Shigella
    • Giardia Lamblia
  • Infective dose of 103 – 105 bacilli: Salmonella
  • Infective dose of 105 – 108 bacilli: Vibrio cholerae

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain, dysentery, and intestinal ulcers. He reports recent travel to an area with poor sanitation. Stool examination reveals a protozoan parasite. All of the following are the features of this condition except:

choices.text: Chromatid bar of the cyst is composed of ribonucleoprotein
Trophozoites produce characteristic flask-shaped ulcerative lesions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trophozoites contain engulfed WBCs

 

Explanation:

The given clinical history suggests amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. These organisms' trophozoites contain engulfed RBCs, not WBCs.

 

Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite

Cyst
  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • Single nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus (Option A)
  • Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBCs)




 
  • 1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate
  • Thick Chromatoid body/ bar:
    • Composition: Ribonucleoprotein (RNP) (Option B)
    • Stain: Iron hematoxylin

 


 


 

Entamoeba histolytica

Entamoeba coli

Trophozoite

  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis

Trophozoite

  • Blunt pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Eccentric karyosome
  • No cartwheel nucleus
  • No erythrophagocytosis

Cyst

  • 1 to 4 nuclei- Quadrinucleate
  • Thick chromatoid body/bar

Cyst

  • 1 to 8 nuclei- Octanucleate
  • Thin filamentous chromatoid body/bar



Trophozoites produce characteristic flask-shaped ulcerative lesions (Option D): These ulcers are most commonly found in the cecum. Ulcers are usually small, round to oval, scattered with intervening normal mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common extraintestinal complication of amoebiasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepatic abscess

 

Explanation:

The most common extraintestinal complication of amoebiasis is a hepatic abscess, often presenting with a distinctive "anchovy sauce" appearance due to the reddish-brown, pus-like material in the abscess cavity.

 

Complications of intestinal amoebiasis:

  • Fulminant amoebic colitis
  • Amoebic appendicitis
  • Intestinal perforation and amoebic peritonitis
  • Toxic megacolon and intussusception
  • Amoebiasis cutis or cutaneous amoebiasis (Option B)
  • Ameboma (amoebic granuloma)
  • Chronic amoebiasis

 

Extraintestinal complications of amoebiasis:

  • Amoebic liver abscess - most common
    • The posterior superior surface of the right lobe is affected.
    • Gross: Anchovy sauce appearance (brown colour fluid)
    • Microscopy: Trophozoites in Pus
  • Rarely, it can also infect the heart, brain, kidneys, spleen, and skin

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a month-long history of abdominal discomfort, intermittent bloody diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss (8 kg), and low-grade fevers. He recently traveled to a rural area with limited access to clean drinking water. Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory findings show mild anemia and elevated white blood cell count. What is the gold standard test to diagnose active infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stool microscopy for trophozoites

 

Explanation

The patient’s signs and symptoms, recent travel history, and exposure to potentially contaminated water raise suspicion of an intestinal infection, particularly of Entamoeba histolytica. Demonstration of trophozoite in freshly passed stool is considered the gold standard microscopic test to diagnose active infection. Trophozoites are absent in asymptomatic carriers.

 

Diagnosis of E. histolytica:

  • Sample collection: Stool is the specimen of choice. Minimum of 3 stool samples should be collected on alternate days (within 10 days) as amoebae are shed intermittently.
  • Stool macroscopy: Foul smelling, copious in amount, dark red in colour mixed with blood and mucus and not adherent to the container
  • Stool microscopy: Direct examination of stool by saline and iodine mount to demonstrate trophozoites and cysts. Demonstration of trophozoites is considered the gold standard microscopic test for active infection.
    • If Trophozoites are seen - Active disease.
    • If only Cyst is seen - Carrier stage.
  • Histology: Intestinal biopsies stained with PAS or H&E stains reveal trophozoites
  • Stool culture
  • Stool Antigen Detection: Fresh/frozen samples are used.
    • ELISA
    • Immunochromatographic test (ICT)
  • Molecular Diagnosis:
    • Nested multiplex PCR
    • Real-time PCR
    • BioFire FilmArray
  • Colonoscopy: May show collar button or flask-shaped amoebic ulcers
  • Miscellaneous finding on stool microscopy: Charcot Leyden crystal

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of cramping abdominal pain, dysentery, and intermittent fever over the past week. Stool analysis confirms the presence of Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites. Which of the following is the primary virulence factor responsible for E. histolytica's ability to adhere to and invade the colonic mucosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gal/GalNAc lectin antigen

 

Explanation:

The Gal/GalNAc lectin antigen is a key virulence factor that facilitates adhesion by binding to glycoprotein receptors on the epithelial cells of the large intestine and the vascular endothelium.

 

Trophozoite of E. histolytica is the invasive form and possesses many virulence factors such as:

  • Gal/GalNAc lectin antigen - principal virulence factor
  • Enzymes
    • Metallo-collagenase
    • Neuraminidase

 

CP47 (Option B), or the Cryptosporidium protein, is the virulence factor of the intestinal coccidian parasites (Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, and Cystoisospora).

 

M protein (Option C) is the principal virulence factor of group A Streptococcus. It inhibits complement-mediated opsonisation by phagocytes.

 

Hyaluronidase (Option D) is an enzyme produced by some bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus and Clostridia species, which breaks down hyaluronic acid in connective tissues. It aids in the spread of infections, but is not a virulence factor of E. histolytica.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea and weight loss after returning from a trip to a region with poor sanitation. Stool microscopy reveals the presence of Charcot Leyden crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

The given clinical history along with the findings of Charcot Leyden crystals on stool microscopy is suggestive that the patient has intestinal amoebiasis. Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for intestinal amoebiasis followed by a luminal agent.

 

Treatment:

  • Active
    • Metronidazole x 10 days
    • Followed by luminal amoebicide - Paromomycin
  • Asymptomatic
    • Paromomycin - For prevention if the patient is a carrier.

 

Tinidazole is used in the treatment of Giardiasis and Trichomoniasis. (Option A)

Nitazoxanide is used in the treatment of Cryptosporidiosis. (Option B)

Praziquantel is used to treat cysticercosis and diphyllobothrium infections. (Option D)

questions.text: A previously healthy 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, severe headache, vomiting, and rapidly progressing confusion. He was diagnosed with meningitis, and his parents report he recently went swimming during a camping trip. Despite treatment, his condition worsens rapidly. Which of the following organisms is most likely causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Naegleria fowleri

 

Explanation:

The clinical history described is most likely suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), which is caused by Naegleria fowleri.

 

Naegleria fowleri:

Naegleria is a free-living amoeba commonly found in warm freshwater environments. In nature, it exists in two forms: cysts and trophozoites.

  • Cyst: Round
  • Trophozoite: Can occur in two forms – amoeboid and flagellated forms.

 

Life cycle:

  • Infective form: Trophozoite.
  • Mode of transmission: Nasal contamination occurs during swimming in fresh, hot water bodies like ponds, rivers, swimming pools, or lakes.
  • CNS invasion: Invades nasal mucosa → Cribriform plate → Olfactory nerve → Brain → Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis.

Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis

  • Causative organism: Naegleria fowleri
  • Occurs in healthy children or young adults with a recent history of swimming in fresh, hot water.
  • Initial symptoms include altered taste and smell (due to involvement of the olfactory nerve), followed by nausea, vomiting, high fever, and meningeal signs such as a stiff neck and positive Kernig’s sign.
  • Secondary symptoms include confusion, hallucinations, lack of attention, ataxia, and seizures.
  • Death occurs within 7–14 days after exposure.
  • Diagnosis:
    • CSF analysis: Thick, purulent CSF with pus cells, elevated protein and reduced sugar level (mimic bacterial meningitis).
    • CSF microscopy: Detection of characteristic trophozoites in CSF (confirmatory).
    • Culture: NNA (Non-Nutrient Agar) - lawn cultured with Escherichia coli.
  • Treatment: Amphotericin B.

 

Acanthamoeba species (Option A): Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba that can cause Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE), a rare and often chronic infection of the brain. GAE usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. It also causes keratitis in contact lens users.

 

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option C): It is a fungal pathogen that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS. It causes chronic meningitis, typically presenting with headache, fever, and neurological changes. Infection is acquired by inhalation of aerosolized forms of Cryptococcus.

 

Listeria monocytogenes (Option D): It is a bacterial cause of meningitis, often linked to foodborne transmission. It generally affects immunocompromised individuals, the elderly, neonates, or pregnant women (extremes of ages).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with 6 weeks of headaches, confusion, and cognitive decline after swimming in freshwater lakes during travel to an area with poor sanitation. Lumbar puncture shows elevated WBCs (predominantly lymphocytes) and trophozoites with distinctive spikes on their surface. Which of the following statements about the causative organism is not true?

choices.text: It is associated with both central nervous system infections and ocular infections.
Both cysts and trophozoites are infective forms.
CT scan shows space-occupying lesions in the brain.
It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is indicative of granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE). The microscopic examination of cerebrospinal fluid revealing trophozoites with spikes points to Acanthamoeba species as the causative organism. Infections caused by Acanthamoeba are typically observed in immunocompromised rather than immunocompetent individuals.

 

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites (Option B).
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes (Option A):
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.


 

Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE)

GAE has an insidious onset, and the incubation period varies from several weeks to months.

  • Symptoms: Confusion, dizziness, nausea, headache, stiff neck and rarely seizure and hemiplegia.
  • In HIV/immunocompromised patients: In addition to GAE, Acanthamoeba produces nasal ulcers, cutaneous ulcers and musculoskeletal abscesses.
  • Pathology: Focal granulomatous lesions in the brain.
  • CSF analysis: Lymphocytosis is seen. However, in patients with AIDS, no cells are seen in CSF.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Brain biopsy: shows trophozoites and cysts.

 

Trophozoite

Cyst
 
  • Show spikes (Acantho - Spikes)

 
 
  • Double-walled, with an outer wrinkled cyst wall.

 

  • Culture: NNA (Non-Nutrient Agar) – lawn culture of Escherichia coli.
  • Molecular methods: Multiplex real-time PCR.
  • Imaging method: CT scan or MRI reveals space-occupying or ring-enhancing lesions in the brain. (Option C)
  • Treatment: Pentamidine + Azole + Sulfonamide + Flucytosine.

 

Vs Balamuthia mandrillaris Infection:

  • Also causes Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE).
  • Life cycle is similar to Acanthamoeba, and has trophozoites and cysts.
  • Unlike Acanthamoeba, Balamuthia encephalitis has been found in immunocompetent individuals (Option D).
  • Differences from Acanthamoeba
    • Trophozoite is fish-shaped.
    • The cyst is smoother.
    • It can occur in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised.

questions.text: What is the suggested treatment for the infection caused by this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tetracycline

 

Explanation:

The image shows a ciliated parasite, which suggests a trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

 

Balantidiasis:

Intestinal infection caused by a protozoan parasite, Balantidium coli. It is the only ciliated parasite of humans.

  • Host: Pig (main reservoir). Man is an accidental host.
  • Morphology: It exists in two forms – Trophozoites and cysts.
  • Infective form: Cyst
  • Life cycle:
  • Clinical features: Profuse diarrhea and dysentery with mucus and blood, fever, nausea and vomiting.
  • Diagnosis (Stool microscopy):
    • Trophozoites: Detected in acute disease. Oval-shaped, exhibits rotatory motility with the help of cilia.
  • Cysts: Found in carriers and chronic cases. Round-shaped, infective form.
  • Both forms are binucleated, and have a large macronucleus and a small micronucleus.
  • Treatment: Tetracycline.

questions.text:
Match the following organisms with their infective forms.

 


	
		
			
			a. Entamoeba histolytica
			
			
			1. Trophozoite
			
		
		
			
			b. Naegleria fowleri
			
			
			2. Cyst
			
		
		
			
			c. Acanthamoeba
			
			
			3. Both cysts and trophozoites
			
		
		
			
			d. Balantidium coli
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a-2, b-1, c-3, d-2

 

Explanation:

 

Organism

Infective form

Entamoeba histolytica

Mature quadrinucleate cyst

Naegleria fowleri

Trophozoite

Acanthamoeba

Both cysts and trophozoites

Balantidium coli

Cyst
